author: Hamza Bhatti
content:
𝟮𝟬𝟭𝟳: My first post got 𝟭 𝗟𝗶𝗸𝗲.
𝟮𝟬𝟮𝟬: My posts averaged 𝟭𝟲 𝗟𝗶𝗸𝗲𝘀.
𝟮𝟬𝟮𝟯: My posts averaged 𝟵𝟬𝟬+ 𝗟𝗶𝗸𝗲𝘀.
𝟮𝟬𝟮𝟱: My posts now average 𝟯,𝟬𝟬𝟬+ 𝗟𝗶𝗸𝗲𝘀.

BUT

In between all these years:
~ I stayed consistent.
~ I kept showing up.
~ I strategized.
~ I destrategized.
~ I tried again.

It took me 9 years to crack LinkedIn.

Yet from the outside,
It looks like I came and conquered overnight.
But NO, just like you, I struggled!

That’s how personal brands, businesses, & confidence are really built.
Not overnight. But over time.

author: Hamza Bhatti
content:
My manager is biased.
My client is difficult.
My work is boring.
My salary is low.

We repeat these lines like a broken record.

But deep down, we know the truth:
𝗪𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝘃𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗽𝗼𝘄𝗲𝗿 𝘁𝗼 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗴𝗲 𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘀𝗶𝘁𝘂𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻.

We can:
- Switch jobs.
- Learn new skills.
- Walk away from toxic culture.
- Build something of our own.

Yet, instead of acting, we choose to complain.
And that’s the biggest lie we tell others and ourselves.

Life won’t hand us better circumstances.
But it will reward the courage to take better actions.

author: Hamza Bhatti
content:
𝗗𝗼𝗻’𝘁 𝗹𝗶𝘃𝗲 𝗹𝗶𝗸𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂’𝗿𝗲 𝟱𝟬 𝘄𝗵𝗲𝗻 𝘆𝗼𝘂’𝗿𝗲 𝗶𝗻 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝟮𝟬s!

I'm tired of society pressurizing youngsters to think that they need to figure life out.

That's too much pressure on the youngsters.
In your 20s, you should be:
- Testing
- Learning
- Experimenting
- Conceptualizing
- Get new jobs
- Live curiously
- Meet new people
- Trying out new stuff
- Try small businesses and ideas and art...

Figure yourself out by exploring, failing, building, and living!

content:

𝗣𝗮𝗿 𝗞𝗮𝗿𝗮𝗰𝗵𝗶 𝗸𝗮 𝗸𝗼𝗶 𝗻𝗮𝗵𝗶 𝗵𝗮𝗶.

author: Hamza Bhatti
content:
𝗜 𝗱𝗼𝗻’𝘁 𝘁𝗿𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗽𝗲𝗼𝗽𝗹𝗲 𝘄𝗵𝗼 𝗮𝗿𝗲𝗻’𝘁 𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗱 𝘁𝗼 𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗺𝗮𝗹𝘀.

The way you treat animals tells so much about you.

If a stray animal shows up at your door or on your street,
- Don’t turn away.
- Feed them.
- Care for them.
- Show them love.

Empathy can’t be reserved only for humans while ignoring every other living being.

author: Hamza Bhatti
content:
𝗗𝘂𝗰𝗸𝘆 𝗕𝗵𝗮𝗶’𝘀 𝗮𝗿𝗿𝗲𝘀𝘁. 𝗪𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗯𝗿𝗮𝗻𝗱𝘀 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝘂𝗹𝗱 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻 𝗳𝗿𝗼𝗺 𝗶𝘁?

Saad-ur-Rehman, aka Ducky Bhai, got arrested due to allegations of promoting online g@m_bling. This incident is a wake-up call for all brands working with influencers:

𝗡𝘂𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗮𝗿𝗲𝗻’𝘁 𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘆𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴.
Yes, he has millions of followers, but reach without responsibility can lead to serious consequences.

𝗔𝗻 𝗶𝗻𝗳𝗹𝘂𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗿 𝗶𝘀 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗮𝗺𝗯𝗮𝘀𝘀𝗮𝗱𝗼𝗿.
Their actions reflect your brand values, for better or worse.

𝗗𝘂𝗲 𝗱𝗶𝗹𝗶𝗴𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝗺𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿𝘀.
Partnering without vetting an influencer’s past activities, values, and collaborations can put your brand at risk.

𝗧𝗮𝗸𝗲𝗮𝘄𝗮𝘆 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗯𝗿𝗮𝗻𝗱𝘀:
Think beyond metrics. If you partner with an influencer, don’t just look at their followers; look at their integrity, alignment with your values, and long-term credibility.

Influence that’s not anchored in trust builds popularity, but it doesn’t build legacy.

author: Hamza Bhatti
content:

and BRANDS LOVE THIS!

content:

author: Hamza Bhatti
content:
𝗗𝗲𝗮𝗿 𝗜𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗼𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘁𝘀,

I know the word that scares you the most:
𝗣𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗼𝗻𝗮𝗹 𝗕𝗿𝗮𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴!

Putting yourself out there in front of the world can feel terrifying.
Every post feels like you’re standing under a spotlight you never asked for.

But here’s the thing:
For your career and your growth, you can’t hide forever.

The good news?
You don’t have to become someone you’re not.
You don’t have to share your deepest secrets.

You just have to talk about your work:
- Work in progress → share your process.
- Lessons learned → insights from projects or challenges.
- Tools & resources → what helps you do your job better.
- BTS → a peek into how you approach your work.
- Wins & milestones → big or small achievements worth noting.
- Educational tips → practical advice others can apply.

Introverts, you can build a personal brand without losing your personal space.
Do it your way that feels safe and true to you!

author: Hamza Bhatti
content:
𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘀𝗮𝗹𝗮𝗿𝘆 𝗶𝘀 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗲𝗻𝗼𝘂𝗴𝗵!

I was alive when 6 figures was "a great salary"
It was not that long ago, either.

In a 100k/200k salary you could:
- Pay for children’s expenses
- Afford a rent
- Live comfortably
- Eat well.
- In an ideal situation, you can even take 1-2 vacations.

But now it's next to impossible.
Here's what you can do.

Remember, opportunities are rising faster than inflation.

→ If you don't get paid enough: 
↳ Network strategically on LinkedIn to get a better job.

→ If you want an extra income stream:
↳ Do the side hustle. Learn new skills like video editing, designing, or writing.

→ If you want to be your boss: 
↳ Hire yourself and use LinkedIn to find clients.

The only thing stopping you is YOU.
So remember: You can complain or you can win. But you can't do both!

author: Hamza Bhatti
content:
𝗪𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗱𝗼𝗲𝘀 𝗧𝘂𝗿𝗸𝗲𝘆 𝗵𝗮𝘃𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗣𝗮𝗸𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗻 𝗱𝗼𝗲𝘀𝗻’𝘁?

It’s about how life is respected!

I saw stray dogs sleeping peacefully on sidewalks.
Cats resting in shop corners, cafes, and on benches.
People walking beside them, without fear and disgust.

So much peace in presence.

No harassment.
No discrimination.

In how well-fed and groomed the animals are.
In how calm the environment feels, like the city breathes peace.

Why not us? Why not Pakistan?
If Istanbul can do it, So can we.

author: Hamza Bhatti
content:
Things my teachers cared about:
- Why didn’t you cut your hair?
- What color is that tie?
- Why are your sleeves folded up?
- Why are your shoes white and not black?
- Why are you not standing straight in the assembly?

They cared about everything except what really mattered!

I wish just one teacher had:
- Helped me choose a path based on my personality.
- Encouraged me to pursue an unconventional career.
- Supported me instead of trying to discipline me.

But NO.
They forced me to fit in. And I was never meant to.
It became a battle that I fought silently, every day.

If you’re a teacher reading this, please:
Be more than a rule-enforcer.
Be a mentor. Be someone your students trust.
Because you’re holding the future in your classroom.
style_notes: Reflective, narrative, motivational, critical of traditional schooling

author: Hamza Bhatti
content:
LinkedIn > Instagram
There, I said it.

Why, you ask?
That’s the same question I’ve been asking myself for the past one year. I finally have the answer.

I have over half a million people who follow me on Instagram. I make all my money on Instagram. But there’s one thing Instagram doesn’t have:

That is our LinkedIn community.

That is people who want to learn something, who want to progress in life, who want to share their success stories, who want to inspire others, who comment "CFBR" to help strangers they have never met.

I haven’t met 99% of you, and yet I deeply feel so connected with all of you.

At the end, it’s all of us together who make this the best platform on social media.

author: Aleena Shahid
content:
I watched a suspense movie without skipping…which is rare.

I usually tap ahead every few minutes.

Cause I am impatient, try to guess the ending, and skip all the build-up part.

But this time I didn’t.
I needed to figure out who the stalker was before they revealed it.

So I could be like, “yep. called it.”

And I realized…that’s exactly how your content should feel.
It should give people enough context to feel like they’re inside the story...

like they know the stakes, the tension, the “why now.”

So how do you actually create that?

1. Set the scene
“Client project failed” → forgettable
“3 days from launch & the devs ghosted.” → now I care.

2. Show where this moment fits
Was this your first client? A turning point? Let people know why it mattered.

3. Add small stakes
What did you risk? What was on the line? Even tiny tension makes people stay.

Context-led content works because it lets your reader feel the moment before they try to learn from it.

It turns a post into a scene. And scenes are what we stay for.
style_notes: Instructional, narrative, practical guidance, suspense metaphor

author: Aleena Shahid
content:
We complain a lot about Pakistan.
The power cuts. The internet drops. The poor education.
The endless little roadblocks that make work feel 10x harder than it should be.

But here’s the thing nobody talks about...
→ Our campaigns are on billboards in London.
→ Our words are selling products in Dubai.
→ Our code is running in Silicon Valley.

Half the time, people don’t even know it’s us.
→ We’ve built startups from bedrooms.
→ Turned 3G into 7-figure freelance careers.
→ Made brands look world-class without charging NY rates.

We’re not “waiting to be discovered.” We’re already building, shipping, and delivering for the world.
Every roadblock is fuel. Every setback is a dare.

That’s the real Pakistan. Messy. Chaotic. Relentless. And absolutely unstoppable.

author: Aleena Shahid
content:
Only a tiny % of your audience is ready to buy right now.

Everyone else?
- They’re in research mode.
- They’re watching. Not acting.
- They’re problem-aware but not product-ready.

Most content accidentally ghosts your warmest leads.
You don’t need more content. You need smarter content, built for 3 types of people:

1. “I think I have a problem, but I’m not sure yet.”
Give them checklists, posts naming the problem, client stories.

2. “I know I need help, but I don't know the best option.”
Give them comparisons, real results, why X didn’t work and what you did.

3. “I’m ready, but I need to trust you first.”
Give them FAQs, process, micro testimonials.

Want help mapping your content to real buyer stages? That’s literally what I do. DMs open (Only 1 slot available)

author: Aleena Shahid
content:
I went missing. (Yes, again. For the 67th time.)

But this time…it was for all the good reasons:
+ I onboarded 2 dream clients. (super-busy)
+ I revamped my website (and 4 sub-domains).
+ I built my design & dev team for MVP project.
+ I wanted to be more clear on my strategy & work.
+ I didn't want to LinkedIn just for the sake of doing it.

And somewhere in this break…I found my groove.

Before this glow-up break, I was running on autopilot.
- Work was “working.”
- Clients were happy and satisfied.
- Growth looked good from the outside.

But everything still felt off.
I was showing up but not really there. Burnt out, bored, and barely connected to the things I’d built.

So I hit pause. And:
→ Focus on chasing fulfilment instead of grind
→ Revisit the 2025 goals I crushed despite doubt
→ Rebuilt my space, my energy, and how I show up

Till the 31st December 2025, here's what I plan to do:
+ Creative space for things I’ve been waiting for “someday”
+ Work that fits into my life, not the other way around
+ Post on my socials and blog with clearer intention
+ Keeping my peace at the top of the priority list

Because life’s too precious to be wasted in a loop you don’t love.

author: Aleena Shahid
content:
I used to overthink everything I wanted to do.
- Should I do this?
- What if it sounds dumb?
- What if someone smarter calls me out?

But here’s what I’ve learned:
Most things that change the world look stupid at first.
1. Colonel Sanders → Rejected 1,000+ times at age 65.
2. JK Rowling → 12 publishers rejected Harry Potter.
3. Walt Disney → Fired for “lacking imagination.”

Imagine if they’d listened. Imagine if they’d stayed quiet to “look smart.”
The fear of looking stupid is sneaky. It keeps you in the background. It convinces you to wait. To play it safe. To blend in.

But safe doesn’t build anything.

So here’s what I’m telling myself lately:
+ Say the idea.
+ Share the post.
+ Ask the question.
Even if it feels awkward. Even if your voice shakes.

Looking stupid is temporary. But staying stuck? That can last years.

Ps: What's the one thing you always wanted to try but fear that people might call it stupid or a dumb idea?
